basics.name: Aidan Scannell
basics.label: PhD Researcher at University of Bristol
basics.summary: I am a PhD researcher investigating data-efficient machine learning for the control of robotic systems. I am particularly interested in uncertainty quantification in model-based reinforcement learning and as a result a lot of my work focuses on Bayesian non-parametric methods, specifically Gaussian processes and variational inference.

work.company: University of Bristol - Bristol Robotics Lab
work.summary: My research is focused on data-efficient learning for the control of robotic systems. EPSRC Centre for Doctoral Training in Future Autonomous and Robotic Systems (FARSCOPE).

Alongside my PhD I am a teaching assistant for 1) [Machine Learning COMS30007](https://www.bris.ac.uk/unit-programme-catalogue/UnitDetails.jsa?ayrCode=19%2F20&unitCode=COMS30007), 2) [Robotic Systems COMSM0012](https://www.bris.ac.uk/unit-programme-catalogue/UnitDetails.jsa?ayrCode=19%2F20&unitCode=COMSM0012) and previosuly 3) [Intelligent Software Systems EMATM0042](https://bit.ly/2Rn2mwx).
highlights_old: I help students understand both the mathematics and the intuition for how we construct ML models and perform inference.
This role has definitely made me a believer that "you never really learn something until you teach it".

I must say that teaching has not only honed my ability to communicate my unerstanding of a concept but it has also prompted me to think about the many other ways a concept can be understood and thus explained.

education.summary: [Extending BDI Agents to Model and Reason with Uncertainty](https://www.aidanscannell.com/project/uncertain-agentspeak/)
courses: Technology and Context of Robotics and Autonomous Systems - 67%

awards.title: British University Snowboard Slalom Champion
awards.summary: In the 2017-2018 season I won all National British University Slalom Competitions. I have also podiumed in several British University SnowboardX and Slopestyle competitions.

awards.title: Starting to Teach
awards.summary: Acquired the knowledge and skills to establish myself as a confident, enthusiastic and effective teacher who is able to engage, encourage and develop students' learning.

awards.title: Full Sporting Colours
awards.summary: Awarded full sporting colours for outstanding achievement in snowboarding.

awards.title: The Bristol PLUS Award
awards.summary: For undertaking a wide range of tasks to further enhance student skills - only 700 out of 23000 achieved this awards per annum.

awards_old.title: Gold Crest Award
awards_old.summary: Achieved through completion of the engineering education scheme.

awards_old.title: Nissan Rose Bowl
awards_old.summary: Awarded the Nissan Rose Bowl for the best team at the North Regional Assessment Day.

volunteer.summary: I volunteer as a STEM ambassador, offering my time and enthusiasm through engagement with children both inside and outside of the classroom.
I collaborated with Code Club and Bristol Libraries to set up and run a Code Club for young people aged 9-13 at Junction 3 Library in Easton, Bristol.
Each year, as part of Formula Student, students design, build and race a single seat race car.
highlights: Finished 2nd in the National Class 2 competition in 2013/2014, I was then selected as the Drivetrain lead.
This role improved my communication skills as I was leading weekly presentations.
I developed my leadership skills through setting realistic objectives, effectively allocating work to the appropriate team members and monitoring outcomes.
Organised multiple weekly training sessions, demonstrating my ability to plan and run events smoothly.
Negotiated competitive prices for a growing member base within an inherently expensive sport.

Responsible for aiding the smooth running of the club and helping to organise the annual university ski trip, with circa 1500 participants, working under pressure to manage people in high stress situations.
Awarded the ‘Team of the Year’ award and full colours for my performances and contributions to the sport.
